messageBody:
Hi,

Over the weekend I had a play with creating the kind of keyboard mapping
(ie using all 4 rows) you're talking about for XFree86/Xorg/Other-xkb
-using-X-servers.
I haven't got it to work yet since I've found almost no documentation on
the xkb format.

But here is what I decided on after some fiddling:
Map the letters from most common to least.
Map on the 3th (home) row first, then on the 2nd (above home), then the
4th (below home) and finally on the 1st (the number row).
On each row map alternately to the left and right hands so the letters
are evenly divided.
Map the index/home column (4, r, f, v, 7, u, j, m) first then the key to
the 'inside' (5, t, g, b, 6, y, h, n) and then the outside keys
progressively.
Carry on until you have no more letters.

I think it produces a nice symmetrical keymap, but I might be a tiny
touch biased :)

I've uploaded the perl script I used to make the keymap.
If anyone knows how xkb works and can tell me what I've got wrong I'd be
eternally (for small values of eternal :) grateful.

Ph.D. wrote:
>
> Jean-François Colson skribis:
> >
> > amd64_hacker wrote:
> > >
> > > What sort of layout should a QS keyboard have
> > > anyway?
> >
> > Let's take a very wide text written in QS and estimate
> > the frequency of each character. After that it would be
> > relatively easy to make a Dvorak QS keyboard for
> > English.
>
> Right.
>
> > tim_rice09 wrote:
> > >
> > > A possible answer to this, build a new keyboard
> > > that may not even have to have a shift key.
>
> I don't think it's practical or necessary to build a new
> keyboard. Move the ten digits on the top row to the
> shift positions on the QWERTY row. Now you have
> 36 keys on four rows. That's almost enough for the
> QS letters. Place the least used letters in a shifted
> position and the next least used letters on the top row.
>
> --Ph. D.
>
>
